name.text: 29.2.4.15 spherical polar coordinates div surface Integral

questiontext.text:
Using spherical polar coordinates \((r, \theta, \phi)\), and the vector field \(\underline{F} = r2 \underline{\hat{r}}+r^2 \sin \theta \underline{\hat{\theta}}\), evaluate the integral \(\displaystyle \iiint_V \underline{\nabla} \cdot \underline{F} \mathrm{d}V\) over the sphere given by \(0 \leq r \leq a\).

generalfeedback.text:
Using spherical polar coordinates \((r, \theta, \phi)\), and the vector field \(\underline{F} = r^2 \underline{\hat{r}}+r^2 \sin \theta \underline{\hat{\theta}}\), we aim to evaluate the integral \(\displaystyle \iiint_V \underline{\nabla} \cdot \underline{F} \mathrm{d}V\) over the sphere given by \(0 \leq r \leq a\).

As we are calculatin the volume integral over a sphere of radius \(a\) at the origin, we know that we'll have \(\mathrm{d}V = \mathrm{d}\phi \mathrm{d}\theta \mathrm{d}r\) and bounds from outer to inner most of: \([a, 0], [\pi, 0], [2\pi, 0].\) Now calculating \(\underline{\nabla} \cdot \underline{F}\) for spherical polar coordinates: \[ \begin{aligned} \underline{\nabla} \cdot \underline{F} &= \underline{\nabla} \cdot( r^2 \underline{\hat{r}}+r^2 \sin \theta \underline{\hat{\theta}})\\ &=\frac{1}{r^2}\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left((r^2)(r^2)\right) +\frac{1}{r\sin\theta} \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}\left((r^2 \sin \theta) (\sin\theta)\right) +\frac{1}{r\sin\theta} \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi}\left(0 \right)\\ &=4r + 2r\cos\theta \end{aligned} \] Now Bearing in mind that the Jacobian for spherical polar coordinates is \(J=r^2\sin\theta\), we can evaluate the volume integral as follows: \[ \begin{aligned} \iiint_V \underline{\nabla} \cdot \underline{F} \mathrm{d}V &= \int^{r=a}_{r=0} \int^{\theta=\pi}_{\theta=0} \int^{\phi=2\pi}_{\phi=0}{@expression@}\ \mathrm{d}\phi\ \mathrm{d}\theta\ \mathrm{d}r \\ &= \int^{r=a}_{r=0} \int^{\theta=\pi}_{\theta=0} \left[{@inner_int_indef@}\right]^{\phi=2\pi}_{\phi=0}\ \mathrm{d}\theta\ \mathrm{d}r\\ &= \int^{r=a}_{r=0} \int^{\theta=\pi}_{\theta=0} {@inner_int_def@}\ \mathrm{d}\theta\ \mathrm{d}r\\ &= \int^{r=a}_{r=0}\left[{@mid_int_indef@}\right]^{\theta=\pi}_{\theta=0} \ \mathrm{d}r\\ &= \int^{r=a}_{r=0} {@mid_int_def@} \ \mathrm{d}r\\ &= \left[{@out_int_indef@}\right]^{r=a}_{r=0}\\ &={@out_int_def@} \end{aligned} \]
